title: UX: use case for --recursion-limit
body:
In one of the recent BF PRs (https://github.com/datalad/datalad/pull/4526#discussion_r425815358) @mih raised a discussion on either we need `--recursion-limit` at all?! And the target use cases were quite sparse.  While scrolling a lengthy `diff` output where I wanted to check what changes have happened since previous publish of `///`, use case came up, which would have been especially nice in conjunction with some `diff --stat` or alike: to limit diff to the specified depth.  For me to get an overview of changes, I think something like `datalad diff --recursion-limit 2` should be sufficient.  If I could have per each hit there get a stat as well (especially if that entry is a subsuperdataset) on +-~datasets, +-~files (where + - added, - - removed, and ~ - changed)    , would have been useful and I think --recursion-limit could be of use there.
But altogether it is not really a "huge" usecase to just decide to keep --recursion-limit for ;)  Just wanted to share, feel free to close
